country where skilled labour is abundant (and hence cheap) than where it is scarce
Market failures in directing technological change
Market forces alone cannot deliver Pareto optimal (i.e.
socially efficient) due to at least two types of
externalities: GHG emissions that cause climate damage and knowledge spillovers that benefit firms
separately: once the favourable intellectual property right regimes (i.e. the laws or rules
on protection and enforcement) are in place, a price on carbon that corrects the emission externality is
sufficient to induce optimal level of green technological change. Acemoglu et al.
that subsidizing clean technologies (and not dirty ones) is also necessary to break the lock
changes often are based on climate
considerations only and neglect secondary externalities and environmental costs of technology choices
(such as loss of biodiversity due to
up of bioenergy use). The scale of adverse side
carbon technologies in the energy sector
Representation of the innovation process in modelled decar
A variety of models are used to generate climate mitigation pathways, compatible with 2°C and well
below 2°C targets. These include Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs), energy system models,
computable general equilibrium models and age
nt based models. They range from global (Chapter 3)
to national models and include both top
energy technologies, which comprises the development and diffusion of
gy options, but also investments to increase energy efficiency, is a key
technology cost developments are one of the factors that determine the speed
and magnitude of the deployment in climate
economy models. The modelling is informed by
the empirical literature estimating rates of cost reductions for energy technologies
literature relies on the extrapolation of historical data, assuming that costs decrease either as a power
law of cumulative production, exponentially with time
or as a function of technical
. Another approach relies on expert estimates of how future
costs will evolve, including expert elicitations
echnology costs may evolve exogenously or endogenously
. In the first case, technology costs are assume
d to vary over time at some predefined rate
generally extrapolated from past observed patterns or based on expert estimates
he influence of cost and diffusion
assumptions may be evaluated through sensitivity analysis.
In the second case, costs are a
a choice variable within the model. For instance, technology costs decrease as a function of either
researching’ is applied to a wide range of
to model improvements in the efficiency of energy use
